title: Can you solve the private eye riddle? - Henri Picciotto

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the slime-lines on the victims?

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: What factors should you consider when forming beliefs, and whether you have ethical duties to believe certain things.

options.label: C
options.text: How to determine what is true in a situation.

options.label: D
options.text: How to communicate with others effectively.

multiple-choice.question: What is the view that evidence is the only thing that ought to determine what you believe called?

options.label: A
options.text: Evidentialism

options.label: B
options.text: Pragmatism

options.label: C
options.text: Subjectivism

options.label: D
options.text: Objectivism

multiple-choice.question: According to W.K. Clifford, what is the moral requirement of following the evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: It is only rational to believe what the evidence suggests.

options.label: B
options.text: It is morally required to have well-informed, accurate beliefs.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only important to follow the evidence in certain situations.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not morally required to follow the evidence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the argument presented by some philosophers that refusing to follow the evidence is a way of being dishonest with oneself?

options.label: A
options.text: That having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining the ethical way to act.

options.label: B
options.text: That there's something unethical about being dishonest, and refusing to follow the evidence is a way of being dishonest with oneself.

options.label: C
options.text: C: That there's no need to follow the evidence if it's not convenient.

options.label: D
options.text: That following the evidence is only important in certain situations.

multiple-choice.question: According to the theory of the ethics of belief called pragmatism, what can sometimes make it right to believe something even without strong evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The strength of the evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: The practical considerations of the situation.

options.label: C
options.text: The opinions of others.

options.label: D
options.text: The convenience of the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: The Simpsons were able to integrate the neighborhood without any problems.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the community in New York that became a prototype of the postwar American suburb?

options.label: A
options.text: Levittown, Illinois

options.label: B
options.text: Levittown, New York

options.label: C
options.text: Levittown, New York

options.label: D
options.text: Levittown, California

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why people of color were unable to take advantage of favorable lending rates for buying homes after World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: They were unable to afford the homes.

options.label: B
options.text: They were unable to meet the credit requirements.

options.label: C
options.text: Racial covenants restricted them from certain neighborhoods, and government programs labeled neighborhoods of color as bad investments.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the massive freeway projects of the mid-20th century on neighborhoods of color?

options.label: A
options.text: They led to an increase in property values.

options.label: B
options.text: They led to a decrease in pollution.

options.label: C
options.text: They disproportionately cut through redlined neighborhoods, accompanied by heavy industry and pollution.

options.label: D
options.text: They had no effect on neighborhoods of color.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of white families in the US owned their homes as of 2020, compared to Black families?

options.label: A
options.text: 74% of white families and 44% of Black families

options.label: B
options.text: 90% of white families and 10% of Black families

options.label: C
options.text: 50% of white families and 25% of Black families

options.label: D
options.text: 25% of white families and 50% of Black families

title: Can you survive the creation of the universe by solving this riddle? - James Tanton

multiple-choice.question: If you're a particle of matter in a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation, what will happen to you if you're not destroyed by antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: You'll be absorbed by a nearby black hole.

options.label: B
options.text: You'll be left alone amidst the chaos.

options.label: C
options.text: You'll be the seed of a future galaxy.

options.label: D
options.text: You'll be destroyed by a nearby star explosion.

multiple-choice.question: In the game devised by the ring of particles, what happens to particles of matter and antimatter when they are adjacent to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They form a new particle of matter.

options.label: B
options.text: They form a new particle of antimatter.

options.label: C
options.text: They annihilate each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They change into a different type of particle.

multiple-choice.question: If you're standing in a circle of 27,182 cubes, where each cube is either matter or antimatter, how can you program your device to identify safe spots?

options.label: A
options.text: By counting the number of matter cubes in the circle.

options.label: B
options.text: By counting the number of antimatter cubes in the circle.

options.label: C
options.text: By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle and adding +1 for each matter cube and subtracting -1 for each antimatter cube.

options.label: D
options.text: By looking for patterns in the arrangement of the cubes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "Russian doll" of fundamental particles in the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the structure of the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the process of particle annihilation.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the idea that a pair never forms around an existing cube.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the idea that each inserted plus was immediately followed by a minus.

multiple-choice.question: What will happen to a matter cube if its sum eventually hits zero when scanning around the circle?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be left alone amidst the chaos.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be the seed of a future galaxy.

options.label: C
options.text: It will be annihilated by its antimatter partner.

options.label: D
options.text: It will change into a different type of particle.

title: Building the impossible: Golden Gate Bridge - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What were the two familiar spires in the mid-1930s that would help support California's Golden Gate Bridge?

options.label: B
options.text: The California Spires and the Golden Gate Monument

options.label: C
options.text: The 22,000-ton towers in Pennsylvania

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The bridge's construction was too expensive

options.label: C
options.text: Moving the bridge's towers across a continent

options.label: D
options.text: The bridge's location was too difficult

options.label: B
options.text: A cantilever bridge

options.label: C
options.text: A rope bridge

options.label: D
options.text: A steel bridge

options.label: A
options.text: To make it more visible to passing ships

options.label: B
options.text: To make it less visible to enemy aircraft

options.label: C
options.text: To match the color of the strait's natural backdrop

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: D

title: The myth of Narcissus and Echo - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What did Hera do to Echo after discovering her duplicity?

options.label: A
options.text: She banished Echo from the kingdom.

options.label: B
options.text: She forced Echo to marry Zeus.

options.label: C
options.text: She silenced Echo so that she could only repeat the last words another said.

options.label: D
options.text: She turned Echo into a mountain nymph.

multiple-choice.question: What was the prophecy given to Narcissus' mother about his life?

options.label: A
options.text: He would live a long life, but only if he married a river nymph.

options.label: B
options.text: He would live a long life, but only if he never really knew himself.

options.label: C
options.text: He would live a short life, but only if he became a great hunter.

options.label: D
options.text: He would live a long life, but only if he never fell in love.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Echo's conversations becoming dull and her company undesirable?

options.label: A
options.text: She became a popular figure in the kingdom.

options.label: B
options.text: She was invited to more social gatherings.

options.label: C
options.text: She grew dispirited and eventually wasted away.

options.label: D
options.text: She became a successful businesswoman.

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of Narcissus' rejection of Echo?

options.label: A
options.text: He was punished by Nemesis, the goddess of revenge.

options.label: B
options.text: He was rewarded by Zeus, the king of the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: He was left alone, but eventually found true love.

options.label: D
options.text: He was turned into a flower.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Narcissus' encounter with his reflection in the pool?

options.label: A
options.text: He became confident in his appearance and began to pursue romantic relationships.

options.label: B
options.text: He became obsessed with his reflection and eventually wasted away.

options.label: C
options.text: He became indifferent to his appearance and continued to live his life as usual.

options.label: D
options.text: He became ashamed of his appearance and hid from the world.

title: How do jetpacks work? And why don't we all have them? - Richard Browning

multiple-choice.question: Why was a massive spacecraft easier to send flying than a single pilot?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the spacecraft had more mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the spacecraft had a more powerful engine.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the spacecraft had a more efficient engine.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the spacecraft had a smaller gravitational force.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary tool for flight in modern jet engines?

options.label: A
options.text: A series of tightly packed blades.

options.label: B
options.text: A jet fuel injection system.

options.label: C
options.text: A huge volume of air that is sucked in and expelled.

options.label: D
options.text: A combustion chamber.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in creating a jetpack?

options.label: A
options.text: Managing the weight of the engine.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a powerful enough engine.

options.label: C
options.text: Producing a large enough thrust.

options.label: D
options.text: Achieving stability and control.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key feature of the Jet Suit developed by Richard Browning?

options.label: A
options.text: A single engine strapped to the back.

options.label: B
options.text: A pair of micro-engines on each arm to split and balance the thrust.

options.label: C
options.text: A advanced computer system to manage the engines.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated flight time of the Jet Suit?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 10 minutes.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 5 minutes.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 30 seconds.

options.label: D

title: What is “normal” and what is “different”? - Yana Buhrer Tavanier

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "normal" mean in the context of statistics?

options.label: A
options.text: A single data point that is considered average.

options.label: B
options.text: A pattern of diversity that follows a bell curve.

options.label: C
options.text: A value that is considered exceptional or unusual.

options.label: D
options.text: A measurement that is always accurate.

options.label: A
options.text: It is too difficult to calculate.

options.label: B
options.text: It does not account for body fat percentage.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only used for men.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used for women.

options.label: A
options.text: Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Western, Educated, Interesting, Industrialized, and Democratic.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Hermann grid illusion

options.label: C
options.text: Ponzo illusion

options.label: D
options.text: Kanizsa triangle illusion

multiple-choice.question: What is the historical significance of the concept of "normal" in the context of the Eugenics Movement?

options.label: A
options.text: It was used to promote acceptance and inclusion.

options.label: B
options.text: It was used to justify exclusion, violence, and extermination.

options.label: C
options.text: It was used to promote equality and fairness.

options.label: D
options.text: It was used to promote diversity and inclusivity.

title: The myth of Gawain and the Green Knight - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: Who burst into the castle during King Arthur's party and proposed a game to the court?

options.label: A
options.text: A wicked sorceress

options.label: B
options.text: A towering knight riding an emerald steed

options.label: C
options.text: King Arthur's nephew, Sir Gawain

options.label: D
options.text: Morgan le Fay

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition of the Green Knight's game that the bravest warrior present had to accept?

options.label: A
options.text: They would have to defeat the Green Knight in a physical fight

options.label: B
options.text: They would have to attack the Green Knight with their own axe, and he would return the blow in one year and one day

options.label: C
options.text: They would have to answer a riddle posed by the Green Knight

options.label: D
options.text: They would have to complete a series of tasks set by the Green Knight

multiple-choice.question: Why did Gawain accept the hospitality of the castle's lord and lady?

options.label: A
options.text: He was seeking shelter from the foul weather

options.label: B
options.text: He was invited to rest at their home until his meeting with the Green Knight

options.label: C
options.text: He was seeking to impress the lord and lady with his bravery

options.label: D
options.text: He was seeking to gain favor with the lord and lady

multiple-choice.question: What was the strange request made by the castle's lord in exchange for his hospitality?

options.label: A
options.text: Gawain had to give him whatever he gained during his day at the castle

options.label: B
options.text: Gawain had to complete a series of tasks set by the lord

options.label: C
options.text: Gawain had to answer a riddle posed by the lord

options.label: D
options.text: Gawain had to defeat the lord in a physical fight

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the Green Knight's game, as revealed at the end of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the bravery of King Arthur's knights

options.label: B
options.text: To test the honor of King Arthur's knights

options.label: C
options.text: To test the loyalty of King Arthur's knights

options.label: D
options.text: To test the wisdom of King Arthur's knights

title: Can you solve the birthday cake riddle? - Marie Brodsky

multiple-choice.question: How can you determine the number of candles on the giant's cake?

options.label: A
options.text: By counting the number of lit candles on the cake.

options.label: B
options.text: By marking the first candle you reach and backtracking to the start.

options.label: C
options.text: By testing a series of hypotheses about the giant's age.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a calculator to estimate the number of candles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most efficient solution to determine the number of candles on the giant's cake?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the guess by 1 each time.

options.label: B
options.text: By increasing the guess by 4 each time.

options.label: C
options.text: By doubling the guess each time.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a random number generator.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it necessary to mark the first candle you reach?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep track of the number of candles you've passed.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that you don't get lost in the tunnel.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine whether you're at the starting candle.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the candles from going out.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using a systematic approach to determine the number of candles?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows you to reach high numbers quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the number of roundtrips you need to make.

options.label: C
options.text: C) It increases the accuracy of your estimate.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the task more enjoyable.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to be systematic in your approach to determine the number of candles?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid getting lost in the tunnel.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the candles from going out.

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that you don't miss any candles.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of roundtrips you need to make.

title: Why do cats have vertical pupils? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: Why do the pupils of different animals vary in shape?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the eyes from harsh weather conditions

options.label: B
options.text: To adapt to different lighting conditions and ecological roles

options.label: C
options.text: To enable animals to see in different colors

options.label: D
options.text: To enhance the sharpness of their vision

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the pupils of house cats?

options.label: A
options.text: They are horizontally elongated and shrink into slits in bright light

options.label: B
options.text: They are vertically elongated and expand dramatically in dark light

options.label: C
options.text: They are round and remain the same size in all lighting conditions

options.label: D
options.text: They are crescent-shaped and change shape depending on the environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of having horizontally elongated pupils like those of goats?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to see in low light conditions

options.label: B
options.text: It enables them to detect objects at a distance

options.label: C
options.text: It provides them with a near-360-degree view and sharp, horizontal images

options.label: D
options.text: It helps them to judge the distance of their target

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pinholes in the pupils of nocturnal geckos?

options.label: A
options.text: To project separate, sharp images onto the retina

options.label: B
options.text: To help the gecko judge distance without having to move

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb most wavelengths of incoming light

options.label: D
options.text: To enhance the sensitivity of the gecko's vision

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans have round pupils?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a lower priority for us to see certain dimensions of a scene in extreme focus

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a result of our evolutionary history as social animals

options.label: C
options.text: Because it enables us to see a larger picture in relative detail

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a result of our ability to see in low light conditions
